item.title: Someone Got A Tattoo Of Bart Simpson As Drake Because Why Not
item.description:
Runnin’ through the 6 with my D’OH’s. (Sorry.)

A guy in Toronto recently asked for ink of Drake, as Bart Simpson, set to a Toronto backdrop. And Drake-as-Bart-Simpson-in-Toronto is what he got.

Franz Stefanik / Via franzstefanik.tumblr.com

T.dot tattoo artist Franz Stefanik would sketch random things that he'd put in a vending machine. It's a "cool chance" for customers to get a design for cheap, he told BuzzFeed Canada.

Set at $80 a tat. "I draw a bunch of fun stuff that goes in there," he said.

Franz Stefanik

Well, one guy came in specifically for a sketch Frank posted to Instagram a week ago.

instagram.com

content.description: Set at $80 a tat. "I draw a bunch of fun stuff that goes in there," he said.
I want this sh*t forever mine, ever mine, ever mine...

item.title: Starbucks' Six Crazy New Frappuccino Flavors Include Red Velvet Cake And Cotton Candy
item.description:
Will you try them all?

Today, Starbucks announced that it's launching six new Frappuccino flavors, available for a limited time.

Starbucks

They're actually based on fan favorites from the "secret menu" of flavor combos customers have cooked up.

Starbucks / Via frappuccino.com

Red Velvet Cake Crème

What it tastes like: "A confectionery-inspired blend of chocolaty chips, mocha sauce, raspberry and vanilla syrup, topped with whipped cream. Perfectly sweet and velvety smooth."

instagram.com / Via starbucks.com

content.description: What it tastes like: "A confectionery-inspired blend of chocolaty chips, mocha sauce, raspberry and vanilla syrup, topped with whipped cream. Perfectly sweet and velvety smooth."

What it tastes like: "A sweet and sour mix that brings lemonade and vanilla together. Finished perfectly with whipped cream and a caramel sugar sprinkle. When life gives you lemons, sip this… upside-down?"

What it tastes like: "Cinnamon dolce syrup blended together with coffee, white chocolate mocha sauce and vanilla bean, topped with whipped cream and a cinnamon dolce sprinkle. Sweet and spicy … that’s how we roll."
What it tastes like: "Take our standard Vanilla Bean Crème Frappuccino®, add raspberry syrup, blend it together, finish with whipped cream and boom, you have a round trip ticket to magic land."

What it tastes like: "Toffee nut syrup, blended with coffee then topped with a dark caramel sauce, whipped cream and a mocha drizzle. More than a classic flavor combo it's a flavor collision of chocolate, nuts and caramel."
What it tastes like: "Start with the Vanilla Bean Crème Frappuccino®, add hazelnut syrup, blend together and finish with whipped cream. A sip of cake flavor in every bite."

item.title: 13 Facts About Sleep Paralysis That Will Keep You Up At Night
item.description:
Let’s talk about what really happens when you wake up and can’t move. Spoiler alert: It’s scary AF.

Jenny Chang / BuzzFeed

It feels kind of like you woke up dead.

"Most patients say the same thing to describe sleep paralysis: that it feels like you woke up dead. You know that your mind is awake and your body is not — so you're trapped, essentially," Michael Breus, Ph.D., clinical psychologist and fellow of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine, tells BuzzFeed Life.

ABC / Via lostoceanic815.blogspot.com

And it's way more complicated than a nightmare.

"It is the complete opposite, actually," Breus explains. When you enter deep REM sleep, your brain tells the body's voluntary muscles to relax and go into almost a state of paralysis, which is called atonia. Atonia actually helps protect the body from injury by preventing you from acting out the physical movements in your dreams. In other parasomnias, such as sleepwalking or REM sleep behavior disorder, atonia does not occur properly and the voluntary muscles move while the mind remains asleep, which is why people can sometimes do crazy things in their sleep and be totally unaware of it.

In sleep paralysis, the body remains paralyzed in REM atonia while the brain awakens and the eyes start to open, explains Breus. Sufferers become alert in a transient conscious state, but they are unable to move voluntary muscles or speak. Although involuntary muscle movement, like breathing, is not affected, there is often a sensation of chest pressure, which is why many people wake up from sleep paralysis gasping to take a deep breath. Episodes can last anywhere from 20 seconds to a few minutes.

FX / Via rollergirlsarebatshitcrazy.tumblr.com

It happens when you're falling asleep or waking up.

Sleep paralysis can occur during one of two transitions in the sleep cycle. The body must go into REM sleep, and it must come out of it, but sleep paralysis occurs when the body has trouble making these transitions. If it happens when you're falling asleep, it's called hypnagogic sleep paralysis, whereas if it happens during waking it's called hypnopompic, Breus explains. Unfortunately, why the body can't transition smoothly is still unknown.

cartoonnetwork.com / Via bustle.com

View Entire List ›

content.description: Let's talk about what really happens when you wake up and can't move. Spoiler alert: It's scary AF.

item.title: These Insane Videos Show People Playing Music While Having Brain Surgery
item.description:
Not only is it possible, sometimes it is imperative.

Videos of Brazilian man Anthony Kulkamp Dias playing the Beatles' song "Yesterday" as his brain was undergoing surgery have been making the rounds online.

"I played six songs at certain times," he said to The Telegraph. "My right hand was a bit weaker because that was the side that they were operating on. So I stopped and rested. I was interspersing songs and talking with them."

youtube.com

Being active and conscious during brain surgery helps doctors monitor for injuries to the patient's brain in real time. (Warning: Brains.)

Vilevi / Getty Images

This is possible because, unlike the rest of the human body, the brain does not actually have any pain sensors.

Dawidkasza / Getty Images

View Entire List ›

group.description: Not only is it possible, sometimes it is imperative.

item.title: 19 Versions Of Pizza From Around The World
item.description:
Home is where stuffed crust is.

Lamacun, Turkey

Thin and crispy bread is topped with minced meat, veg, and herbs in the most common version of this Turkish takeaway staple – but don't fear, vegetarians: Lots of vendors are getting creative and offering plenty of alternative toppings. If you're looking for a breadier pizza-style dish in Turkey, go for some pide.

Learn how to make your own.

instagram.com

Tarte Flambée, France

Pizza with a French twist – could cuisine get any more perfect? France's favourite flatbread is generally topped with fromage blanc, onion, and bacon.

Learn how to make your own.

instagram.com

Okonomiyaki, Japan

This cross between savoury pancake and pizza in Japan is pure genius. Batter is grilled on the hob, and depending on the region and your tastes, you can have any number of ingredients grilled in with it or added after, but never forget the mayo, Okonomiyaki sauce, and bonito fish flakes to garnish.

Learn how to make your own.

instagram.com

Lángos, Hungary

In Hungary, you should get your doughy, cheesy fix with lángos. Deep-fried dough is generally topped with sour cream, cheese, and garlic. It's a popular takeaway and homemade treat.

Learn how to make your own.

instagram.com

View Entire List ›

content.description: Thin and crispy bread is topped with minced meat, veg, and herbs in the most common version of this Turkish takeaway staple – but don't fear, vegetarians: Lots of vendors are getting creative and offering plenty of alternative toppings. If you're looking for a breadier pizza-style dish in Turkey, go for some pide. Learn how to make your own.
Pizza with a French twist – could cuisine get any more perfect? France's favourite flatbread is generally topped with fromage blanc, onion, and bacon. Learn how to make your own.

This cross between savoury pancake and pizza in Japan is pure genius. Batter is grilled on the hob, and depending on the region and your tastes, you can have any number of ingredients grilled in with it or added after, but never forget the mayo, Okonomiyaki sauce, and bonito fish flakes to garnish. Learn how to make your own.

In Hungary, you should get your doughy, cheesy fix with lángos. Deep-fried dough is generally topped with sour cream, cheese, and garlic. It's a popular takeaway and homemade treat. Learn how to make your own.

Sfiha is basically an open-faced meat pie, and it's popular across the Middle East, including in Syria and Lebanon. The topping is typically made of minced lamb, pine nuts, and onions. Learn how to make your own.
Pizza meets sandwich in this Polish street-food favourite. Cheese, mushroom, and onion are baked onto a baguette and topped with ketchup. Learn how to make your own here.

Bulgogi is a beloved dish in Korea – beef is marinated in a soy sauce, sesame, and spice mixture and grilled. So throw it on a pizza and boom: You have a brand-new takeaway treat with a Korean twist. In recent years this combo become a popular commodity in the country. Learn how to make your own.
This popular Palestinian flatbread is topped with onions, spices, and nuts, and typically served with chicken. It literally has all the good things. Learn how to make your own.
Get back to basics in Italy with a classic Neapolitan pizza. Italian bread dough is topped with tomato and mozzarella for the cheesy, saucy goodness we know and love. Learn how to make your own.

This stuffed bread boat is a must-have takeaway in the nation of Georgia. Filled with cheese and baked with an egg, the savoury dish can be eaten any time of day, but it's most definitely the perfect option when you're craving breakfast pizza. Learn how to make your own.

Coca is a Spanish flatbread, often topped with veg and Spanish sausage, but it's popularly served around the country with any number of toppings. The bread is a little stickier and oilier than your typical pizza, but hey, bring on the grease! Learn how to make your own.
This holy grail of pizza is a popular novelty in Glasgow and Fife. From simple origins (frozen pizza, brown sauce, and a deep fryer) come truly amazing things. Learn how to make your own here.
In Lebenon, no breakfast is complete without this spicy flatbread. The topping is simple, just oil and spices, but the impact on your taste buds is big. Learn how to make your own.

Different regions of the States pride themselves on their local style of pizza, but Chicago deep-dish has to be one of the most unique. The bready and stuffed pie is a must while you're in the Windy City. Learn how to make your own.

Legend has it that after having a Chinese scallion pancake, explorer Marco Polo asked Italian chefs to create a similar flatbread, and pizza was born. The unleavened flatbread is a typical street food in China and Taiwan. Learn how to make your own.
Smoked meat and hot peppers are the staple toppings for this open-faced Macedonian meat pie. You can add an egg for extra texture and flavour. Learn how to make your own.

This Indian flatbread is similar to naan, but made with whole wheat flour, and is a typical side dish. It can also be topped with veg, meat, or egg and served on its own, pizza-style. Learn how to make your own.
Flammkuchen is a German variant of France's tarte flambée, topped with crème fraîche, smoked bacon, and fromage blanc or quark. Learn how to make your own.

Sweden gets that pizza is the ultimate junk food, so takeaways combined it with another popular late-night order, the kebab. Just look at it: so beautiful, so deadly, so food-baby-worthy. Learn how to make your own.

item.title: This Couple Had A True WTF Moment When They Discovered A Snake In Their Kitchen
item.description:
OH, HELL NO!

On Sunday, Laura Neff was milling about her farm near Charlotte, North Carolina. She discovered a 4-foot-long snake crawling out of her spice cabinet and attempting to eat an egg.

A true WTF moment.

Laura Neff / Via youtube.com

Neff continued, "They are beneficial due to their tendency for eating rodents and eggs, usually outside, of course."

This case turned out a little differently — while the video cuts off short, the snake wound up eating one of their farm eggs. They leave them out on the counter because they are fresh and don’t require immediate refrigeration.

The Neffs said, "It got in through a hole in our laundry room floor, which is now covered by a VERY heavy concrete block and which will soon be permanently plugged."

What a sight.

Laura Neff / Via youtube.com

Neff and her husband allowed the snake to continue his afternoon snack, then helped him out of their farm. Polite farmers!

Neff said, "Using two brooms, a whole lot of patience, nudging, and encouraging, we finally convinced the snake that going out the open window was a MUCH better option than slithering away behind the fridge!"

Laura Neff / Via youtube.com

View Entire List ›

content.description: A true WTF moment.
Neff continued, "They are beneficial due to their tendency for eating rodents and eggs, usually outside, of course."

The Neffs said, "It got in through a hole in our laundry room floor, which is now covered by a VERY heavy concrete block and which will soon be permanently plugged." 

What a sight.

Neff said, "Using two brooms, a whole lot of patience, nudging, and encouraging, we finally convinced the snake that going out the open window was a MUCH better option than slithering away behind the fridge!"

The description of the YouTube video stated, "As soon as we could get its bulk under the brooms, we hefted it out the window, and off it went to the rest of its evening." Neff joked, "And then we drank."

item.title: This "Mean Girls" Deleted Scene May Explain Why Cady Breaks The Plastic Crown
item.description:
This is a side to Regina we’re not used to seeing.

A deleted scene from Mean Girls went viral over the weekend after fans were shocked to see the character Regina George “show a different side".

movieclips.com / Paramount Pictures

Instead of delivering a scathing one-liner to Cady, Regina tells a story about a dollhouse she destroyed rather than let anyone else own it. Fans of the cult classic said that it was a "shame" the scene was cut as it showed Regina's vulnerability and "human side."

Many fans also felt the story about breaking the dollhouse added important context as to why Cady later breaks the plastic prom crown and tosses it out to girls in the crowd, including Regina.

Paramount Pictures

The ~breaking parallels~.

item.title: The Reason Your Fridge Door Is Magnetic Is Pretty Horrifying
item.description:
It’s time for a gruesome lesson.

Pretty much all fridges these days have a magnetic door opening, but it wasn't always that way.

Older fridges used to have a latch opening, that could be opened only from the outside. Which is all well and good, until someone climbs inside.

Batareykin / Getty Images

To make things worse, the rubber around the door would create a seal – to keep the cold in – making it harder for anyone to hear you calling for help.

Obviously most people don't go climbing into fridges, so you might not think this is a big deal. But you're not a small child playing hide-and-seek.

Kelvinator

View Entire List ›

content.description: Older fridges used to have a latch opening, that could be opened only from the outside. Which is all well and good, until someone climbs inside.

To make things worse, the rubber around the door would create a seal – to keep the cold in – making it harder for anyone to hear you calling for help.

Obviously most people don't go climbing into fridges, so you might not think this is a big deal. But you're not a small child playing hide-and-seek.

The act said that all new fridges had to be openable "easily from the inside". A few years earlier, in 1951, California had passed a law that made it illegal to dispose of a fridge where children could access it, and a couple of years after that they added an amendment that required people to remove doors or latches before discarding them. Switching to a magnetic opening and closing mechanism meant that fridge doors would stay closed when you wanted them to, but could be opened from the inside with a little bit of a push.

The above figures come from a paper titled "Behavior of young children under conditions simulating entrapment in refrigerators" that was published in 1958 (and, presumably, would not make it past an ethics board these days). The paper had two key findings: The first was that, when trapped, children tend to push on the door to try to escape; and the second was that 3-year olds can push on average with 10 pounds of force, whereas 5-year olds can push with 21 pounds. The data from the study was used in developing standards for fridge doors.

Old fridges stuck around and can still be found (and crawled into) in garages and backyards. But the number of deaths did fall in the years after magnetic doors became standard. A 1985 study published in Public Health Reports looked at the data from California on how many children between 0 and 9 years old died from suffocation in a fridge or freezer. The researchers found that between 1960 and 1981, such deaths fell by half, from just over 1 child per million to less than 0.5 children per million. (There was actually a spike in the late 1960s, but the researchers put this down to the typical 1950s fridge having a 15-year lifespan.)

item.title: This iPhone Fell To The Bottom Of The Ocean And Recorded The Entire Fall
item.description:
His own version of “Under the Sea.”

Gregory Papadin was vacationing in Menorca, Spain, when his iPhone went for a little swim. The captain of his boat retrieved the phone and he discovered it recorded the entire two-minute drop to the bottom of the ocean floor.

youtube.com / Via youtube.com

Papadin was in the water swimming when an accidental flick of the wrist caused his phone to take a free fall.

Luckily, he had a case on it or he'd be SOL.

Gregory Papadin / Via youtube.com

The phone even caught this fish during the fall.

Also a pretty cool reflection of the sun!

Gregory Papadin / Via youtube.com

THE. STRUGGLE. WAS. REAL.

Gregory Papadin / Via youtube.com
